messageBody:
"Shellman, Joel" wrote:

> I read once that a chess expert will be relatively confused if
> presented with a chess configuration that is impossible to get to in a
> real game because it doesn't match the patterns they are familiar
> with.

The studies you're referring to were undertaken during the analysis of
chess-playing
AI programs. It was included in Peter Frey's book -- an excellent
compilation of papers on the subject.

The finding that, when shown a board containing pieces placed on random
squares, non-experts and experts were essentially identical in their
ability to reconstruct the board, with non-experts holding a slight
edge. (Less mental "interference", no doubt.)

But when shown positions arising from actual games, the experts' memory
was far and away superior, tantamount to total recall (and I will bet
that it was especially keen with respect to the "salient" features,
although there was no way to measure that concept as far as I can
recall) -- while the non-experts did just about as well with real
positions as
with random positions.

However, the point your are trying to make, I suspect, is that code
developed by TDD experts will most likely show some interesting patterns
that differ from code developed
by other folks.

That appears to be Scott's thesis, as well, and I greatly look forward
to the expansion and illustration of those views.
